publicwhip.spmotion: *S2M-3638 Mrs Margaret Ewing: World AIDS Day 2005: Red Ribbon—That the Parliament notes that 1 December 2005 marks World AIDS Day, the international day of action on HIV and AIDS which takes place every year; recognises that last year in the United Kingdom over 8,000 people were infected by HIV/AIDS, while worldwide over 4.9 million people were newly infected, and welcomes the fact that this year World AIDS Day is about wearing the Red Ribbon as a sign of support for people living with HIV and a symbol of hope for the future, and notes that by getting people involved, more people will be aware of the dangers and facts of the disease and will take measures to reduce the risk of infection. Supported by: Mr Kenny MacAskill*, Stewart Stevenson*, Tommy Sheridan*, Mr David Davidson*, Ms Sandra White*, Sarah Boyack*, Ms Rosemary Byrne*, Nora Radcliffe*, Mr Jamie Stone*, Jim Mather*, Patrick Harvie*, Rob Gibson*, Bruce Crawford*, Des McNulty*, Jackie Baillie*, Fiona Hyslop*, Margaret Smith*, Bill Butler*

S2M-3638 World AIDS Day 2005: Red Ribbon (lodged on 28 November 2005) Shiona Baird*, Susan Deacon*, Mike Pringle*, Mr Jim Wallace*, Mr John Swinney*, Fergus Ewing*, Eleanor Scott*, Christine Grahame*, Alex Neil*, Shona Robison*, Mr Adam Ingram*, Donald Gorrie*, Mr Frank McAveety*, Mr Bruce McFee*
S2M-3638 World AIDS Day 2005: Red Ribbon (lodged on 28 November 2005) Mr Kenneth Macintosh*, Margaret Jamieson*, Dennis Canavan*, Chris Ballance*

S2M-3638 Mrs Margaret Ewing: World AIDS Day 2005: Red Ribbon—That the Parliament notes that 1 December 2005 marks World AIDS Day, the international day of action on HIV and AIDS which takes place every year; recognises that last year in the United Kingdom over 8,000 people were infected by HIV/AIDS, while worldwide over 4.9 million people were newly infected, and welcomes the fact that this year World AIDS Day is about wearing the Red Ribbon as a sign of support for people living with HIV and a symbol of hope for the future, and notes that by getting people involved, more people will be aware of the dangers and facts of the disease and will take measures to reduce the risk of infection. Supported by: Mr Kenny MacAskill, Stewart Stevenson, Tommy Sheridan, Mr David Davidson, Ms Sandra White, Sarah Boyack, Ms Rosemary Byrne, Nora Radcliffe, Mr Jamie Stone, Jim Mather, Patrick Harvie, Rob Gibson, Bruce Crawford, Des McNulty, Jackie Baillie, Fiona Hyslop, Margaret Smith, Bill Butler, Shiona Baird, Susan Deacon, Mike Pringle, Mr Jim Wallace, Mr John Swinney, Fergus Ewing, Eleanor Scott, Christine Grahame, Alex Neil, Shona Robison, Mr Adam Ingram, Donald Gorrie, Mr Frank McAveety, Mr Bruce McFee, Mr Kenneth Macintosh, Margaret Jamieson, Dennis Canavan, Chris Ballance, Brian Adam*, Cathie Craigie*, Mr Stewart Maxwell*, Mary Scanlon*, Karen Whitefield*, Richard Lochhead*, Mrs Nanette Milne*, Margo MacDonald*, Tricia Marwick*, Marlyn Glen*, Linda Fabiani*, Robin Harper*, Mr Mark Ruskell*, Mrs Mary Mulligan*, Michael McMahon*, Maureen Macmillan*, Elaine Smith*, Bristow Muldoon*
S2M-3638 World AIDS Day 2005: Red Ribbon (lodged on 28 November 2005) Frances Curran*, Robin Harper*, Rosie Kane*, Carolyn Leckie*, Pauline McNeill*, Cathy Peattie*, Iain Smith*
S2M-3638 World AIDS Day 2005: Red Ribbon (lodged on 28 November 2005) John Scott*
